snippet.textDisplay:
I will play this when I turn 18. 
It's what I'll listen to when I graduate.
This is what everybody will cry to as my future husband and I exchange vows.
And I'll have my pregnant belly listen to it, everyday until they're born.

It's incredible how a mere sequence of chords can contain the beauty and meaning of everything, how so easily it can arise infinity. This is the greatest game of all time

snippet.textDisplay: When I first achieved the specific ending that features this track (Chrono and Marle with the balloons, the one "true" ending as far as I'm concerned) I couldn't help but cry. I was a 17 year-old devirginized  male so I had to turn in my masculinity card but yep, the beautiful song - and the beautiful ending - came together in such a way that it was hard not to feel overwhelmed. The ending was so simple, so touchingly sweet, that I really got hit with the feels. Watching the scene and hearing the music gave me a bittersweet mix of joy for what I'd experienced, hope for what the future may bring, and loss at knowing that such a grand adventure had come to an end. The most perfect ending to one of the most perfect video games ever made.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Gabuman http://www.thonky.com/chrono-trigger/ (click on whichever chapter your save file says).
Although, by the sounds of it, i think you only have some sidequests remaining. You can finish the game by simply going to the "black omen" (the giant floating thing in the sky at 1000 A.D) and beating the final dungeon. It's still recommended to do some sidequests because you're probably under-leveled.

snippet.textDisplay:
There were several ports.

First: PS1 port, pretty much just SNES version with some fmv and horrible loading times.

Second: DS port, 2 new side quests on the end added + fmv from PS1 version, has no loading times, probably best version.

Third: Android/iOS version: Horrible DRM (Just get the pirate version for android if you must), controls are... could be better, it does have the 2 new side quests, but no fmv.

snippet.textDisplay: It's sad to see such a beauty like this game be hidden by it's obscurity. It's always on "best game ever" lists, but it's not as well spoken as Ocarina or FFVII, so no one new plays it, even though Chrono Trigger is probably better than those two. It just goes to show how the quality of a game doesn't matter, what does matter is how popular it is and how well it sells. I hope to god Square Enix does remake this game, or at the very least they should port it to the PS4. So many people will be happy, and so many people will be introduced to this masterpiece of game design.

snippet.textDisplay: This song is a... validation. There is a sense of finality to the tone, and you KNOW that the journey is done. It's bittersweet, and you have to let a lot of things dear to you go, but you can now rest. It's truly over. I love this. This is how ending songs should go, and should be the measure for all ending songs. When I die, I want this to be playing as I close my eyes. :)

snippet.textDisplay: Songs like this, and pretty much everything else about this game, is the reason why this game will most likely sit as my personal all time best game for the rest of my life.  No other game can invoke such emotion, whether it be sadness, horror (the scene with Luca's mom) wonderment, joy or humor from such modest sprites.  Everyone who worked on this game were magicians, and show why this industry should be considered and a viable storytelling medium.

I often think we (the ones that played this masterpiece during the 16 bit days) have been blessed.The SNES was thoroughly squeezed in the graphics and sound department in a way I never expected.Every piece of music in this game is aural magic....no other way to describe it.

Sure,you can download and play it now.But taking that cartridge to the slot,turning it on and being graced by that tick of the clock...just thinking about brings tears to my eyes.

We had it good,boys :*)

snippet.textDisplay:
I remember seeing this game in Nintendo Power, (the cover had the Virtual Boy on it.) and I remember reading for almost a whole hour just being amazed; then I went to the kitchen and showed my mom and said, "I want this game!" She later rented it for me and I couldn't wait till Christmas day of 1995. When I finally got it, I knew it would be my favorite game of all time. No game has affected me like this one has.

Simply put, one of the greatest games of all time!!

snippet.textDisplay: Too all you kids saying you wish you could have been born in the time when CT was released... You were! It was on the DS, and although not a perfect port, it was great. I enjoyed it very much, and even though the exclusive content was nothing more than fetch quests, I dug it very much. You may not have been born in a time when this game was FIRST released, but SquareEnix was kind enough to re-release it to allow you youngsters the opportunity to experience just what we did in 95.

snippet.textDisplay:
I remember the very first time I played this game... The day it was released in the US. I picked it up for a hefty $85. I still have the ticket from the Toys R Us I picked it up at. 1995. I was 8 years old at the time. I played it through in about a week. Between school, homework and other things a kid does, I was engrossed into it's story... I couldn't believe a game like this existed.

Nearly 15 years later, nothing has changed. This game is, and always will be, the greatest game ever created.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sadly, it NEVER received the praise it was due back upon its original release. But its cult following has grown ever since and has been heralded as one of the best games ever made, even by rivals who have made countless attempts to mimic it. Memorable characters, a gripping story, epic music, multiple endings, and all backed by a dream team of artists, composers, and designers.

Chrono Trigger, nothing like it before...or since.

snippet.textDisplay: This theme is so perfect. A group of friends who may never see each other again, one of whom may not even exist any more, going on one last awesome ride through time together. This track encompasses the sheer enjoyment they can get from time travel now they've finished the mission, while also keeping a touch of melancholy. Expertly done.

snippet.textDisplay:
I read in an interview that Mitsuda used to sleep in the studio some nights, while composing for Trigger. Musing alone with his instruments all through the night, amidst (occasional) rest, he came up with many of his pieces. He said that during these times, song ideas sometimes came to him in dreams. 

One of the most memorable pieces he recalled first conceiving in his dreams was... guess.
